column4: General question: I want to accesss my Ubuntu server (running Edgy) via my Ubuntu desktop (also running Edgy) X interface.  Do I need to have X installed on the server?
you can just use SSH i suppose, if you don't want to run graphical applications on the server
yes. or, couldn't you just set up file sharing and do it on the client side?
at any rate, if you just installed the program concerned (say Eclipse) on the server, the X libraries will be installed automatically

Good question.  I'm relatively new to Linux and not sure how to setup file sharing.  However, given that the files I need access to are in my www path, I'm not sure I want them shared for all acess...
err, that's what access control is for ;-) you know, passwords and the like
i'd definitely say so. an NFS or Samba server will do nicely
it's a bot. colors don't lie
Can I install KDE if I've already go GNOME installed?
thank you, but the link didn't answer the basic question: can I have both GNOME and KDE installed on the same system?
to install from Ubuntu... what does that suggest you? ;)

there are only two downsides that i can think of: 1) your Gnome menus get crowded by KDE applications, and your KDE menus likewise  2) if you later decide to uninstall either Gnome or KDE, it's not necessarily very easy
if you install KDE using aptitude instead of apt-get, the latter most probably becomes easier.
thank you.  I use Kate for javascript editing, and thought that if I installed KDE it might run more cleanly.
well, if you run KDE and then (besides Kate) mostly run GNOME programs on it, it'll be just as unclean or worse ;)
ok, any suggestions for a new GUI editor for languages like javascript that run will in GNOME?
i use KDE myself, so not really...
ok. I guess I will have to build a KDE vm and see if I like it any better (have no real preference, just used GNOME and not KDE).

actually, if you use aptitude to install it, i think you'll be able to completely remove it and be back to your GNOME desktop as you left it (perhaps making a new user for KDE might be best, if you really are concerned)
don't take my word on it, but i've done this before
thanks again
